DOC.HEAD: US Attacks Office of Noriega Buddy, Looters Have Field Day
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: At the sledgehammer's final blow, a cheer went up from the crowd outside a house belonging to one of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's closest associates. People poured into the house at a dead run, exultant. They poured out again with bottles of French champagne, silver coffee pots and sequined sombreros. But this was no ordinary looting mission. It was a middle-class crowd for the most part, and they were venting pent-up loathing for the general and all he stood for. ``Democracy has arrived,'' one young man said. ``We don't want these military guys running things. They are thieves.'' Someone emptied a case of campaign-style buttons bearing the slogan: ``Onward with Noriega!'' and began gleefully stomping on them, grinding them flat with a little dance as onlookers applauded. The house belonged to Carlos A. Wittgreen, a businessman believed to be a key player in the maze of front companies hiding Noriega's money-laundering and cocaine-smuggling schemes. ``He's Noriega's right hand,'' one man said as people opened box after box of handcuffs in amazement. The house was sacked after a U.S. armored vehicle bombarded the place. Troops barricaded the street at mid-afternoon Friday and opened fire. They pelted it with tear gas and demanded Wittgreen's surrender over a bullhorn. When no one emerged, they left and the people began running toward the house, cheering. Teresa Bay Guardia sat on the grass nearby, sorting through the files and boxes of documents her teen-agers were hauling out as fast as they could. Their eyes streamed from the biting sting of the tear gas trapped inside, but they were grinning like they'd just won the lottery. ``I'm gathering evidence,'' she said as sofas, office chairs, potted plants and paintings went by at a dizzying clip. ``I have a friend in the opposition I'm giving this to.'' There was a pile of letterhead stationery. Five different companies. Five different addresses. One telephone number. Someone else found a handwritten ledger in a spiral notebook. Page after page of coded transactions, many with Noriega's general staff. Guardia, a U.S. citizen raised in Panama, looked at the pile of documents as though Christmas had come a few days early to Panama. ``I've walked many a mile, been in many a demonstration against Noriega,'' she said. ``This is the first time I haven't been afraid to give my name.'' She said she couldn't understand the international criticism of the U.S. invasion. ``Ask the Panamanians. We're the one's who have been living the situation,'' she said. Even with the lawlessness and looting that has broken out, she said, ``We're delighted.''
